title: 1. Practice Self-Care
content:
Maintain a balanced diet and proper hydration.
Get enough sleep (7-9 hours per night).
Engage in activities you enjoy.
Set boundaries to avoid burnout.
Reduce Screen Time and Digital Overload (e.g. limits on social media use, take breaks from electronic devices or engage in offline activities that bring joy.
2. Emotional Well-being
Practice Gratitude – Keep a gratitude journal or express appreciation daily.
Self-Compassion – Be kind to yourself and avoid harsh self-criticism.
Emotional Awareness – Recognize and name your emotions to process them effectively.
3. Social Well-being
Spend time with supportive family and friends.
Join community groups or online forums.
Engage in meaningful conversations to reduce feelings of loneliness.

title: 4. Cognitive Strategies
content:
Positive Thinking – Reframe negative thoughts with a growth mindset.
Mindfulness & Meditation – Stay present in the moment to reduce anxiety.
Problem-Solving Skills – Approach challenges with a solution-focused mindset.
5. Physical Well-being/ Stay Physically Active
Regular Exercise – Improves mood through endorphin release.
Healthy Nutrition – A balanced diet supports brain health.
Quality Sleep – Prioritize rest to enhance cognitive and emotional functioning.
6. Stress Management/Engage in Mindfulness and Meditation
Practice relaxation techniques such as deep breathing, meditation, or mindfulness.
Use time management strategies to reduce overwhelm.
Engage in hobbies that help you unwind.

title: 7. Purpose & Fulfillment
content:
Set Meaningful Goals – Align daily activities with personal values.
Lifelong Learning – Stay curious and open to new experiences.
Spiritual or Philosophical Exploration – Reflecting on purpose can enhance resilience. Engage in activities that provide meaning and fulfillment.
8. Seek professional help when needed
Talk to a therapist, counsellor, or psychologist.
Use support groups or helplines if feeling overwhelmed.
Medication or therapy may be beneficial for clinical conditions.

title: 6.Epilepsy
content:
What is Epilepsy?
Epilepsy is a neurological disorder characterized by recurrent seizures and convulsions or seizures, which are sudden bursts of electrical activity in the brain. This occurs when a sudden burst of electrical activity in the brain causes the brain cells to not transmit information properly. This causes a disruption or blockage in the brain’s ability to transmit information. These seizures can vary widely in terms of their severity, type, and how they affect the individual. Epilepsy is considered a chronic condition, but with proper treatment, many people can manage their seizures effectively.
Causes of Epilepsy:
Epilepsy can have various causes, though in many cases the exact cause is unknown. Some potential causes include:
Genetic factors
Head trauma or brain injury
Brain infections (e.g., meningitis, encephalitis)
Stroke or brain tumors
Developmental disorders (e.g., cerebral palsy)
Prenatal injury or abnormal brain development
Symptoms of Epilepsy
The primary symptom of epilepsy is recurrent seizures. The nature of the seizures can vary, but common symptoms during a seizure include:
Loss of consciousness or awareness
Muscle spasms, jerking movements, or stiffness
Uncontrolled movements or behaviors (such as lip-smacking or shaking)
Confusion or disorientation after the seizure
Common myths about epilepsy:

title: • Insanity
content:
• Satanic (evil spirit)
• Caused by witchcraft
• Belief that it is contagious (especially by touching or being near a person who has epilepsy)
• Believing that it can be cured by holding a matchstick in your nose and writing something on a piece of paper and then erasing it
Help for someone with a seizure፡
The best and most appropriate treatment or support for people with a seizure is to:-
Carefully remove them from dangerous areas and place them in a comfortable position.
Place a soft pillow under their head.
Help them lie down on their side and rest.
Do not put anything in their mouth to prevent accidents.
Do not light matches.
Do not give them anything to drink
Although epilepsy is not a life-threatening condition, some people die every year from sudden injuries caused by the disease. It is not allowed to put anything in their mouth to prevent accidents. It is not appropriate to light a match, give him something to drink, or hold his hands and feet while he is shaking.
Treatment options
Medications: antiepileptic drugs (AEDs)
Surgical treatment
Lifestyle changes: Adequate sleep, stress management, and avoiding seizure triggers (e.g., flashing lights) can help manage epilepsy.
Vagus Nerve Stimulation (VNS): A device implanted under the skin that sends electrical impulses to the brain to help prevent seizures.
Ketogenic Diet: A high-fat, low-carbohydrate diet that may help control seizures
Support to take medications regularly, stay safe during seizures (e.g., avoid swimming alone or operating heavy machinery)
